page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY OF CHAGFORD
page.content: Chagford is a{Saxon}name, originally spelt as{Kagefort. }It meant{Gorse {Ford,}and Chagford was the gorse spot where the River Teign could be forded. It receives a mention in the{Domesday {Book}which states that "Chageford was held by Dodo in the time of King Edward". {Tin}was extracted from Dart- moor from around 1150 onwards and in 1305 Edward granted Chagford a charter enabling it to hold{Stannary Courts and to check on the tin's quality. During the{Civil War}Chagford was decidedly{Royalist}and in a skirmish outside the Three Crowns Hotel a young Cornish poet,{Sydney Godolphin,}was shot and killed. In the early 1800's woollen mills on the banks of the Teign became very prominent and one of these was used to bring{electric {street lighting}in 1891 to Chagford, the first place west of London.
